data.title: Review with the professors and further selection
data.desc:
search for a small, even reductive, aspect, and exaggerate it, highlight it, give it value to reflect on a bigger thing

imagine what the consequences of a situation would be: what would increasing or decreasing the conflict lead to

what is the feeling linked to the issue?

be critical: there is a continuous narrative about "everything is going to hell," but in reality, the world is always getting better than before

conflict narrative / real conflict

different cultures exist with a different view of reality

more ironic keys can be used, one does not necessarily have to take the theme seriously and convey it in a serious, stereotyped, and classic way

verify that the themes found match the sub-themes of social conflict

book: FACTFULNESS by Hans Rosling exhibition: INEQUALITIES at Triennale TV series: The Handmaid's Tale on Netflix

data.title: generational conflict
data.desc:
focus on conflict

does it make sense to increase it or try to smooth it out?

take data into account, categories are useful

see Alvar Aalto and the 7 cities

data.title: climate change and inequality
data.desc:
it risks being too broad as a theme, we need to narrow it down

let's try not to talk about good or evil, or giving an opinion, but keep both points of view together

focus on the system, not on the struggle between people (silent conflict)

it risks becoming an economic/macroeconomic discussion

what is the real conflict?

data.title: Brainstorming and research on selected themes or new more specific details
generational conflict and privacy
data.desc: There are sounds – like ultrasounds – that are only audible to young people and imperceptible to those who are older.

data.title: historical trauma
data.desc: Historical trauma and the collective memory of past injustices can perpetuate social conflicts across generations, fueling resentment, grievances, and hostility between groups.

data.title: hostile architecture
data.desc: Hostile architecture is a design approach for public spaces that incorporates physical elements (uncomfortable benches, central armrests, spikes, sloped surfaces, etc.) intended to limit or discourage undesirable behaviors, such as sleeping or lingering.

data.title: Accesso alla casa e gentrificazione turistica
data.desc: The proliferation of short-term rentals (like Airbnb) has transformed entire neighborhoods into temporary hospitality zones, drastically reducing the availability of stable housing for residents.

data.title: gated communities
data.desc: Gated communities are residential neighborhoods enclosed and controlled by gates or private surveillance, designed to guarantee security and privacy for the inhabitants and to separate themselves from the surrounding urban space.

data.title: review with assistants
data.desc:
Good research, aspects that intersect different themes

There is no risk of spilling over into other conflicts, but of losing the social dynamics linked to our conflict

Practical advice: risk of superficializing and arriving at a simplified output such as: 'this thing is bad.'

Let's not necessarily project ourselves onto futuristic things, we risk not allowing the user to relate, we don't need this 'noise'

data.title: review with assistants
data.desc:
Clear Conflict, great ironic potential

The aspects we have designed are fine, but we should think about small variations, without changing the core

Some cities want tourists to earn money (city seen as a government that does not primarily want the well-being of its citizens)

We can start working finely on the tone of voice, values, palette, graphic identity, branding (a couple of proposals)

data.title: review with assistants
data.desc:
1 => build a narrative, but first try to think about what the most important message I want to convey is, the message must be one and clear, e.g., a banal example 'a caste of people exploit the few for their advantage,' the idea that a pension is a privilege, we young people feel we have to work until death. Try to explicitly state the film 'cameos' in the project as much as possible to make them immediately noticeable, so even make them too explicit or conversely use them as a reference and try to deviate; if we don't deviate too much, we need to think of an elegant way to clearly articulate this reference, keep somewhat the same narrative line; the risks of the first lie in the careful work on the references, but he still likes it very much, it just needs to be done in a refined way

2 => meh, anyway, basically he likes it, here too the issue of references, here the main critical point to be careful of is the risk of it becoming a bit too silly, a bit an end in itself

The point is that it's important first and foremost to get people to think about social conflict, these scenarios are 'excuses' to talk about social conflict, which of the two conveys the message better? either by taking a radical stance or by remaining completely neutral, so I reason carefully about which of the two scenarios helps to convey the message better; perhaps the first tends to be more radical and the second less, what tone of voice do we want to maintain? what message do we want to convey about social conflict?

data.title: scenario presentation
data.desc:
generational conflict

overturism

historical trauma

data.title: Context
data.desc: Historical trauma does not belong only to the past: through epigenetics, experiences of suffering can leave biological marks that influence subsequent generations. Research on descendants of survivors of wars, genocides, and discrimination shows how collective stress can translate into psychological and physiological vulnerability. Trauma thus becomes an inheritance that is not only cultural but also genetic.

data.title: Topic for consideration
data.desc:
Inherited trauma can be interpreted in different ways:

as a factor of vulnerability, perpetuating stress and distrust;

or as a biological memory, preserving identity and cultural ties.

The open question is whether this inheritance represents a limit to be overcome or an element to be understood and maintained.

data.title: What if
data.desc: In a future where genetic modification is common practice, a pharmaceutical company develops a treatment capable of intervening on the epigenetic markers of trauma. Every individual can choose whether to keep or remove the biological inheritance of pain. Those who decide to eliminate it stop the transmission of trauma to future generations, and also choose to lose the personal memory of the painful experiences from which this inheritance originated.

data.title: definition and cause of the conflict
data.desc: The conflict arises from the differing interpretations of the relationship between memory and well-being: on one side, those who consider genetic erasure a form of prevention, and on the other, those who deem it necessary to maintain the biological trace of the past as an element of historical continuity.

data.title: Agents and dynamics of the conflict
data.desc:
Scientific institutions and research centers: They study the effects of inherited trauma and develop technologies to reduce its impact, with the aim of improving the mental and biological health of populations.

Cultural communities and social groups: They focus attention on the value of shared memory, considering it an essential component of collective identity and historical awareness.

The Public: They oscillate between the desire to lighten the burden of the past and the willingness to preserve the connection to their origins.

data.title: Entity-subject
data.desc: We position ourselves as a biotechnology company that offers the choice between remembering and forgetting.

data.title: Context
data.desc: In the near future, retirement no longer exists for the majority. A ruling class of elderly and retired people lives thanks to the labor of the new generations, who work until death to maintain their privileges. Generational change is only possible for the elites.

data.title: Topic for consideration
data.desc: What happens when the survival of the few is founded on the sacrifice of the many? The social contract becomes a system of biological exploitation, where youth is a resource and old age is a privilege to be protected at all costs.

data.title: What if
data.desc: What if longevity has become the new social privilege? The elderly prolong their lives thanks to the bodies of the young, used as 'biological matter.' Work and the body lose human value, becoming fuel for those who hold the power.

data.title: definition and cause of the conflict
data.desc: Conflict between those who live off privilege and those who sustain it. An integrated system of economic power and biotechnology maintains inequality and hinders generational turnover.

data.title: Agents and dynamics of the conflict
data.desc:
Elderly ruling class: Political power, control of resources.

Young workers: Productive and biological force.

Biotechnology structures: Instruments of exploitation and control.

data.title: Entity-subject
data.desc: A biotechnology company manages human farms for transplants and life extension. It presents itself as a 'guarantor of the future,' but in reality, it transforms the human body into a resource. It is the symbol of a civilization that, in order not to die, devours itself.

data.title: Context
data.desc: In recent years, the phenomenon of overtourism has transformed many European cities, including Barcelona, Venice, and Florence. Mass tourism generates daily discomfort for residents: rising prices, loss of public spaces, and congested streets. At the same time, tourists themselves also experience an impoverished experience: endless queues, overcrowded places, and a lack of authenticity.

data.title: Topic for consideration
data.desc: The core issue is not to establish whether tourism is 'right' or 'wrong,' but to question how sustainable the coexistence is between those who live in the city and those who pass through it. What happens when hospitality turns into exasperation? To what extent are residents willing to defend their daily lives?

data.title: What if
data.desc: What if, one day, citizens had access to a device that allows them to identify and hit tourists with non-lethal weapons, such as BB guns or paintball guns, turning the city into a kind of gamified hunt? The scenario we imagine is one of extreme tourism, where visiting a city is no longer a cultural experience, but a challenge of survival.

data.title: definition and cause of the conflict
data.desc: Definition and reason for the conflict The conflict arises from two opposing needs: The residents want to reclaim their spaces, defending themselves against a perceived invasion. The tourists seek authentic experiences and free access to the cities. The device exacerbates this tension, normalizing the idea that 'hunting tourists' is a legitimate act.

data.title: Agents and dynamics of the conflict
data.desc:
The main actors are: 
The citizens, who become armed players and defenders. The tourists, transformed into collectible targets. The city becomes an arena, where tourism fuels the very conflict that rejects it.

data.title: Entity-subject
data.desc: In this scenario, a technology company specializing in 'playful urban defense' emerges. Its role is to provide tools that respond to the residents' need to reassert control over the city. But at the same time, it intercepts a new market: adrenaline tourism. A short circuit where protest becomes entertainment.

data.title: WHO WE ARE
data.desc:
We are a private company operating in the field of human biotechnology applied to longevity. In a society that has surpassed the natural limits of age and reproduction, our task is to ensure vital continuity through a system of breeding and biological optimization of the new generations.

Young people today represent an essential resource: they are used as a source of 'Linfa' (Sap/Lifeblood), an organic substance indispensable for prolonging the lives of the elderly population. Thanks to our progress in the medical and engineering fields, it is now possible to regenerate organs, tissues, and vital functions by transferring biological components from the healthiest subjects to those in need. Our goal is to guarantee longevity to the elderly population through the exploitation of the new generations.

data.title: PROGRAM'S LIFE CYCLE
data.desc:
Birth → registration and cataloging according to biological and genetic parameters.

Productive Age → entry into the work cycle and controlled physiological maintenance.

Programmed Reproduction → generation of new biological units.

Extraction of the Linfa (Lifeblood/Sap) → progressive harvesting until the subject's natural exhaustion.

Organic Recovery → removal of tissues and organs for regenerative and surgical procedures.

data.title: VISION
data.desc: We imagine a future where life is no longer a universal right, but a resource to be administered precisely. Our mission is to make the longevity of a portion of the population efficient and controlled. A world where every drop of lifeblood finds its purpose.

data.title: DEVICE
data.desc: Our biological management system is composed of two interconnected devices: a personal wearable and a domestic totem.

data.title: WEARABLE
data.desc:
A biometric pendant for the elderly, to be worn around the neck, designed to track in real-time: the Linfa (Lifeblood/Sap) level; vital parameters;

The device constantly sends data to the Totem, ensuring continuous and transparent monitoring of vital performance.

data.title: TOTEM
data.desc:
A desktop object with a minimalist design, about the size of a small household appliance. In the upper section, an interactive screen displays: the profile of the assigned young person; their vital statistics; the availability of purchasable organs or biological components.

The lower section contains reserves of Linfa-based products, ready for daily consumption. The Totem and the Wearable operate in synergy, suggesting when and what to consume to maintain the elderly user's optimal vital parameters.

data.title: MEDICAL KIT
data.desc: a medical kit for the elderly medicines to maintain youth and strength, etc. → imagining that young people possess a special 'sap of youth,' we can play with creating bags of hypothetical materials that grant strength, beauty, etc., like miracle cures syringes for injecting the sap parts of 'synthetic' membranes or organs created from studies on the young patches that gradually release the sap of youth for critical situations pill boxes Petri dish where tissue can be 'grown' starting from that of a young donor device that allows monitoring various parameters (always related to youth, such as a percentage of youth, both physical and mental, and general state of health), but also, for example, to find if there are compatible young people to donate organs (maybe the idea of using identification codes for young people, as if they were just a number) imagining that every elderly person can find a perfect donor → device that allows the extraction and conservation of the 'sap of youth' + related instruction manual labels written with 'donor n.010192,' age, and important parameters (always emphasizing that young people are just a number)? I like the concept of 'sap' and it would be cool to make it a crazy color like neon, silver, or black (?) because it detaches from the idea we have of normal bodily fluids

data.title: WHO WE ARE 1.1
data.desc: A private company identifies an opportunity for profit in the problem of overtourism. It therefore decides to intervene, offering an exasperated citizenry a product, a game, presented as the solution to their discomfort. In this way, the company positions itself above the two conflicting groups, exploiting the tension between tourists and residents to gain an economic advantage.

data.title: WHERE
data.desc:
In the European locations (especially large cities) most affected by this phenomenon.

Some are: -Barcelona -Lisbon -Berlin -Florence -Venice -Rome

*mostly large European cities

data.title: CONFLICT ACTORS
data.desc: citizens vs tourists

data.title: WHY THE CONFLICT EXISTS
data.desc: The core issue is not establishing whether tourism is 'right' or 'wrong,' but questioning how sustainable the coexistence is between those who live in the city and those who pass through it. -What happens when hospitality becomes exasperation? -To what extent are residents willing to defend their daily life?

data.title: WHAT IF
data.desc: What if citizens could hunt tourists to take back the city?

data.title: Speculative SCENARIO
data.desc: We place ourselves in the near future, where the problem of overtourism (already severe today) has not only not been resolved, but has worsened further. Let's imagine a community of exasperated residents who, after years of unheard protests and increasing frustration, find themselves living in an unsustainable situation. Faced with the inertia of the institutions, the desire to find increasingly radical solutions grows among them.

data.title: OUR OBJECTIVES
data.desc:
Exploiting the citizens' discontent and the overtourism crisis to transform collective discomfort into a profitable recreational experience.

Instead of solving the problem, we fuel it, converting social frustration into entertainment and profit.

data.title: PRODUCT
data.desc:
The kit 
The main product sold to citizens is a 'urban hunter' kit, composed of: A Paintball gun, with additional accessories. A Recognition Device, which allows for the identification and collection (tagging/scoring) of tourists.

data.title: GAME RULES
data.desc:
Hunting seasons: the game is structured into seasons (events), determined by the peaks of tourist influx in different cities (for example, Milan in winter, Barcelona in summer).

Team play: players act in groups, collaborating to achieve common goals that determine the community's success. However, there are also individual milestones, which reward single players upon completion of specific personal achievements.

Scoring system: points are accumulated through the 'collection' of different categories of hit tourists, categorized by levels of rarity based on predetermined parameters.

data.title: Le molte proteste contro i turisti nelle città italiane
Tra Italia, Spagna e Portogallo si è tenuta una delle più grandi proteste del movimento contro l’overtourism
Ai movimenti contro l’overtourism la protesta non basta più
Le proteste contro l'overtourism nelle principali città europee
Il 15 giugno in tutta Europa ci saranno manifestazioni contro il turismo. L'attivista italiana: «Il turismo non ci salverà, anzi, mette a rischio il diritto di vivere nelle nostre di città»
tourists' identification

data.title: device
data.desc: a paintball gun to shoot tourists, without hurting them, but disturbing them and creating nuisance.

data.title: Arduino
data.desc: research for the use of an external camera, a screen as a sight (or viewfinder), and a button as a trigger.

data.title: phone integration
data.desc: Following the professors' advice, we opted for using the phone instead of a camera and sight (or viewfinder).

data.title: Web App
data.desc: development of a web app that can use the phone's camera to recognize tourists and insert them into an archive.

data.desc: switching to app development in order to have more control and greater integration.

data.title: Vibrant motor arduino
data.desc: integration of two vibrating motors via Arduino, activated by a button, to simulate the firing effect when the trigger is pressed.

data.title: weapon draft 1.2

data.title: WHO WE ARE 2.1
data.desc:
Transition into a DAO (Decentralized Autonomous Organization) to return control and decision-making power directly to the community.
Reclaim is a community-managed solution addressing an issue that affects all its participants, creating a product that is an actual solution to the issue of overtourism.

data.title: website new direction
data.desc: after becoming a DAO and changing our communication style, we give much more importance to the website, that has to contain our intentions, ideals, and our product. we use Antigravity to code the website.
